text: doctors have been warned to look out for
a dangerous workout trend called
dry scooping that some gym goers are
doing
it involves eating protein-rich powder
supplements neat rather than diluting
them in water as recommended by
manufacturers
researchers who are giving a talk at a
u.s medical conference are worried that
teenagers others may try it spurred on
by a flurry of internet videos of the
fat
let's talk now to nutrition scientist
bridget benelum who is from the british
nutrition foundation
what's the problem with this
so the main active ingredient of these
powders is caffeine and they vary in
terms of their level of their caffeine
content from anything to about
equivalent to one cup of filtered coffee
to up to three or even more cups of
filtered coffee so that's potentially a
lot of caffeine in one dose and now if
you're preparing these made up to
manufacturers instructions that's one
thing but if you're just eating the dry
powder then you may be getting that dose
much more quickly and you may also be
having more than the manufacturer
recommends so i think the key issue here
is the potential for having much too
much caffeine at once and what we don't
know is how this impacts on general
population now we have research around
caffeine and performance in athletes but
of course when you're looking at an
athlete that person is usually has a
team around them looking after them
checking their medical health they'll be
aware of the medical records but of
course in the wider population there can
be a lot of variability in terms of how
sensitive people are to caffeine we
probably all know that there are some
people who have who say can't have
coffee in the evening or they can't
sleep so for example if you're getting a
lot of caffeine at one go there is the
potential for unpleasant side effects
now they are not necessarily serious it
could just be feeling a bit jittery as
perhaps we all have when we've had too
much coffee but if you are sensitive to
caffeine or if you have an underlying
medical additional condition that you
may not be aware of then there is a
potential risk there of just having much
too much caffeine at once okay
and do you believe that is dangerous if
you have much too much caffeine at once
well there is certainly the potential
for negative effects on your health and
i think the difficulty is we just don't
know we don't have the research on these
powders we don't know what they're doing
we don't know how people are taking them
but clearly they are taking them uh
according to these videos in a way that
isn't uh made up according to the
manufacturer's instructions which is
usually a scoop of powder and then made
up to be a drink where you're you would
be getting probably the caffeine more
slowly you would be getting water at the
same time so i think you know there's
really no need to take supplements
before you go to the gym or before you
train but if you are going to take them
then it's really important then you
follow the manufacturer's instructions
and that you don't take more because
these ingredients that are powerful and
potentially
can affect your health it's interesting
that you say you don't need supplements
at all or all these kind of
so-called nutritional drinks at all
before you do some exercise or go to the
gym why do you say that
so we know from research in athletes
that some of these ingredients have the
potential to benefit performance but
that really is at that very elite level
where people are doing very high level
training
in the margins but you know if you're
just going to the gym to keep generally
fit you want to build muscle you want to
build your endurance you really don't
need anything extra your body's very
capable of adapting to exercise and
benefiting from it and you don't need
extra supplements in order to support
your body to do that
thank you very much for talking to us
thank you bridget benlam from the
british nutrition foundation
